newsitem.title: SINGAPORE: Malaysian firm passes on tender for corn/soybeans.
newsitem.headline: Malaysian firm passes on tender for corn/soybeans.

text.p: Malaysia's Soon Soon Sdn Bhd passed on a tender for 100,000 tonnes of U.S. corn and soybeans after finding the price too high, traders said on Friday.
"They passed. They felt the price was too high for them," a trader for a U.S. commodity house based in Singapore said.
Dealers said Soon Soon was looking for a combination cargo of corn and soybeans.

This included one Panamax-sized vessel of about 50,000 tonnes of corn and soybeans for January-February delivery. The second Panamax with 50,000 tonnes of corn and soybeans would be for May delivery, the traders said.
The price for the corn quoted by traders ranged between US$142-$145 a tonne C&F. The soybeans were offered at over $300 a tonne C&F.
"Soon Soon was looking for something at about $140 a tonne for corn and about $295 a tonne for the beans," a dealer for a European commodity house said.
Another dealer said the Malaysians may also be interested in taking a look at the prospect of China exporting in the first quarter of 1997.
"I understand they want to see the Chinese corn first," one trader said.
It was the second time Soon Soon had passed on the tender. No date was set by the company for a new tender, the traders said.
